title: How many confirmed cases of COVID-19 in the U.S. will be reported for the week starting 21 February 2021?
preds: https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/covid-data/covidview/index.html The current 7 day average is around 78,000, putting the covid cases for this week somewhere around 546,000. I don't think it's likely that there are more than 600,000 cases.

Feb 21 - 55195
Feb 22 - 59462
Feb 23 - 71802
Feb 24 - 70768 Need to average over 100k a day for rest of week to exceed 600k.

The current 7-day average of new cases is 70,715, according to Worldometers data.  This would mean a weekly total of just under 500k.  It seems unlikely, at this point that the weekly total would exceed 600k.
Trending pattern indicates lower new infection rates.

Vaccine rates are rising and covid cases are dropping at a rate that makes it exceedingly unlikely for the number of cases to be above 600,000 for the week. Additionally, there are no events this week that would increase social activities above the norm and cause cases to spike (Superbowl, Christmas, Thanksgiving, etc.)

While I originally forecasted higher numbers, there didn't seem to be a Valentine's Day/Superbowl spike, and numbers have fallen a good deal since I last forecasted, so I think that there is a higher probability of fewer than 600,000.

There has been a large decline in covid cases since January 15th and are now at around 50 to 60 thousand cases a day. Given that data, cases are more likely to be less than 600,000 since they have fallen so far and are expected to continue falling or stay relatively low (at least low for the US). However, there is always a chance we could experience another spike, which is why it could go above 600,000.
CDC Covid Data Tracker: https://covid.cdc.gov/covid-data-tracker/#trends_dailytrendscases
The overall trend in Covid-19 cases has been decreasing steadily since December. The data shows that it might either plateau soon, but it will still be below 600k.
Approx 55k per day = forecast estimate 385-425k in one week
Its 500,000 On Feb 22, 2021. Case numbers are dropping exponentially. 100,000 in one week, the rates would need to be going up not down.
To reach 600k 85,714 per day needed on average. Day 1. 21/02 Sunday 56,495
The week of February 15th saw less than 500K cases, so next week is expected to be on par or have fewer cases.

Last 7 days looks to be about 500k cases.  Drop in cases slowing down, but don’t expect rates to go up.  Sticking with bin 1. 18,19 and 20th average about 70k.  At this rate would have 490k in 7 days. 
https://covid.cdc.gov/covid-data-tracker/#trends_dailytrendscases But if the source is not here but here https://ourworldindata.org/coronavirus-data-explorer?zoomToSelection=true&time=2020-03-01..latest&country=USA~EuropeanUnion~GBR~FRA&region=World&casesMetric=true&interval=daily&smoothing=0&pickerMetric=total_cases&pickerSort=desc as John Hopkins proxy, then last 3 days is more like 80k. Still below threshold, but bears watching. 600k in 7 days is 85,714 per day
Mother Natures Lockdown may have done it.

I am suffering from confirmation bias, only building arguments and looking for data as to why I'm right. Today, this: https://ourworldindata.org/covid-cases?country=IND~USA~GBR~CAN~DEU~FRA.  February 15 -- the height of the storms and power outages -- saw the low in new confirmed cases. It's been climbing since then. Seven-day average hit the inflection point on February 18.  Will today plus the next 6 days see 85,715 cases per day on average? It was 71,500 yesterday (weekend day) but 110,000 on Friday --> a 2-day average of 90,750.  And 90,750 > 85,715.  Watching closely....

January 31 to February 17 saw a series of winter storms swept across the US, driving ice and freezing temperatures and, ultimately, the Texas power outages (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/February_2021_North_American_winter_storm). To what extent did that weather diminish testing activity -- both demand and supply? Because diminished testing means diminished CONFIRMED cases.  Weather across the US will generally warm up this week (https://weather.com/forecast/national/news/2021-02-20-rain-snow-midwest-northeast-south-active-northwest). Will that open windows for testing activity, not only for those who might feel ill this week but also for some who felt ill ten days ago but did not or could not go to testing centers?
on 2/20 there were 71k per day or 497k with a slight bump up.

1. The trend is declining and the 7-day average cases have to exceed 85,714 to meet 600,000 cases in total and 107142 to meet 750,000 cases. It is possible during November 2020, but the trend is increasing at that time. 
2. Even though three variant virus was detected, it won't make a huge change in the total cases. Those virus already appeared at the end of 2020 and there are approximately 1605 cases diagnosed as variant virus which is a really small amount in 600,000 total cases. 
3. Although the new cases might not rise as rapid as before, the trend for February 15 to February 19 is increasing toward 78018. There is a possibility for the 7-day average to increase back to 85000 even though non of us would like to see that. 
4. Still the extremely cold weather has prevent people from testing in person or through test-kits. The transportation is also affected.

New case rates are down almost 70% from the peak in January and are expected to continue this downward trend.  New cases are averaging around 85K cases per day. 85K * 7 = 595K This is just slightly under 600K.

Confirmed cases have been heavily declining since mid-January. In addition, testing is at its lowest since October 2020, as testing center switch their efforts to vaccine distribution.
https://viz.covid19forecasthub.org/
https://ourworldindata.org/coronavirus-data-explorer?zoomToSelection=true&time=2020-03-01..latest&country=~USA&region=World&testsMetric=true&interval=smoothed&perCapita=true&smoothing=7&pickerMetric=total_cases&pickerSort=desc
Covid cases have been trending downwards and would need a large spike to go over 600,000 new cases.

Weekly cases at about 560k and still dropping. Leaving some in over 600k on possibility of a spike. https://ourworldindata.org/coronavirus-data-explorer?zoomToSelection=true&time=earliest..latest&country=~USA&region=World&casesMetric=true&interval=weekly&perCapita=true&smoothing=0&pickerMetric=total_cases&pickerSort=desc

Cases have been recently declining which leads me to believe that it is unlikely for a major spike to happen, especially because events like the Super Bowl, Mardi Gras, etc. have already happened and have been accounted for in cases. However, to account for recency bias, I'm giving it a 20% that a possible spike could happen seeing as that seems to be a trend in the past. Although, with more vaccines being given out and not much time left until the deadline, I still say it is unlikely that there will be more that 600,000 cases in that week.
Number of positive cases declining significantly across the country daily. No effect yet seen from superbowl gatherings or recent openings of restaurants, bars and schools in major cities.

With more doses of the vaccine being released, covid cases should be less frequent and the CDC data shows that cases are decreasing currently.  The CDC also stated that the national peak of covid cases was 314,093 in January 2021, so the number of cases should not significantly rise above that for the week starting February 21st.

Rate below 90k per day now and still reducing.  90k per day is 630k in a week.  We are still a week out but no sign yet of rate of fall slowing.
600k in a week would be an average of 85k per day. We are close to that now Comment in my first forecast implies should have had higher pc on bin 1.  I’m guessing didn’t do my maths with enough rigour.  Should pay more attention.

The American Center for Disease Control currently places the forecasted weekly cases for the week of February 21 at almost 770,000. (https://covid.cdc.gov/covid-data-tracker/#forecasting_weeklycases) However, Johns Hopkins' Coronavirus Research Center mentions that almost all states are experiencing a decreasing number of new COVID-19 cases (https://coronavirus.jhu.edu/testing/tracker/overview), so there is a possibility that new weekly cases could be less than what the CDC is forecasting.
Now forecasting 375-550K based on recent data over last two weeks. Vaccinations also appear to be back on track, but more important at this stage is I think the consistent messaging from Government

The CDC forecast compiles dozen of different models based on the current case count.  The projections are slightly under 600K cases for the week of February 21st.   https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/cases-updates/forecasts-cases.html

https://ourworldindata.org/coronavirus-data-explorer?zoomToSelection=true&time=2020-03-01..latest&country=USA~EuropeanUnion~GBR&region=World&casesMetric=true&interval=smoothed&smoothing=7&pickerMetric=total_cases&pickerSort=desc
94k current 7 day average for US and dropping.  But not JHU figures.
Bin 1 looking quite likely now.

First, simplest possible back of the envelope calculations:
1) If the downward trend in cases were suddenly to stall, that would put us at about 656,400 cases.
2) To hit the 750,000 mark, average daily cases would need to increase by 14%--the crowd here is heavily discounting this possibility, but it's not out of reach.
3) To drop below 600,000, average daily cases would need to decrease by 8.6%.  Not unreasonable, and a lower drop than recent trend, with an average drop of almost 20% a week for the last four weeks. Next, what might be driving changes in case rates?  The weather may have driven testing down, but the reduction in cases over the past week has only been slightly above trend, and positivity rates are also down: https://coronavirus.jhu.edu/testing/individual-states It's hard to discern any Super Bowl surge.  There are reports of variants gaining traction but not actually leading to material increases in case counts, and even if the rt for variant cases is 50 to 70% higher than for "COVID Classic", the base isn't yet high enough to drive real change in overall counts.   My hunch is that the cold weather this week is leading more people to stay home generally (obviously it's leading more people to stay inside, but that alone wouldn't lead to a decrease if people, say, went out to eat indoors rather than out).  Vaccinations are beginning to have an effect at the margin.    Overall, I think it's more likely than not that cases will continue to decline for the next couple of weeks, at least, but I honestly can't put my finger on a solid explanation why.  Various public health and political leaders have been busy congratulating the public for the reductions, and attributing them to increased adherance to distancing and masking, but I'm not seeing big positive changes in those.  To the contrary, multiple states and cities have been reopening restaurants and, to a lesser extent, bars, which in the past has reliably lead to increases in cases.   I'll continue to ponder this.
one week on from Superbowl and no notable impact. I am going purely off the data series however.
due to the rise of covid tests coming out and with many people getting them the numbers should fall exponentially

May be just enough of a bump from Lunar New Year celebrations, Valentines/Presidents Day weekend gatherings, February break (2/15-2/19 for NYC schools, maybe others) to bring the total over the last weekly average of ~600K but also may not clear 750K due to these until the week after.
The 7 day moving average has been rapidly declining since mid-January from over 200,000 to around 95,000.

Was there a Superbowl surge? From exposure to symptoms takes 2-14 days for 99% of cases, median 4-5 days --> February 11-12, and 97.5% of cases symptomatic with 11.5 days --> February 18/19 (https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/hcp/clinical-guidance-management-patients.html). Highest case counts last week were February 11 and 12, 105.6k and 99.6 respectively. But overall trend in new cases is steadily down since January 9, 252k/day --> 84k/day by February 13.  Seven-day average as of yesterday is 95k/day. Is that the "real" number? @SE_Meyer makes the clever observation that the cold spell this week may have inhibited testing. Testing does seem to have been a bit lower last week, and in any case has been dropping since post holiday peak on January 18 and mini peak on January 30 (https://covidtracking.com/data/charts/us-daily-tests). Multiple news reports from around the country noted closed testing centers because of winter weather. CDC reports tests per 1000 people dropped 25% -- although that could be because there is less transmission and therefore fewer people seeking to be tested. Still, I'll assume that numbers of new cases reported over the past 7 days were lower than they would have been without winter storms. The NWS has winter storm warnings in place for 120 million Americans between now and Tuesday, 2/16.  Might we see a "bounce" in new cases after that, as folks bundled up at home decide to go out and wait in line to be tested?   @Harvey-the-Rabbit notes the challenge of new, more transmissible, strains. CDC suggests new variants are firmly in place in Florida and California, centers of gravity for the pandemic in the US (https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/transmission/variant-cases.html). CDC models suggested the new variant would become the dominant one in March, with the steepest part of the growth curves in mid-March (https://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/volumes/70/wr/mm7003e2.htm?s_cid=mm7003e2_w#F1_down).    The ending of any Super Bowl surge is downward pressure on these numbers, but new strains emerging is slight upward pressure over timeframe of this question. Quite possibly winter weather suppressed testing and therefore led to fewer new reported cases this past week.   Assume current 7-day average continues --> 665k new cases for the week ending 2/27.  
Assume 90% of current 7-day average continues --> 598.5k new cases for the week ending 2/27.  
GJO model implies: 595.5k new cases for the week ending 2/27.  
CDC Ensemble modeling on 2/8 forecast 579,998 cases for the week ending 2/27.   609.75k is point estimate.

About to drop below 600k with two weeks to go and a defined downward trend in place.  The 3% for over 600k would be if we see an uptick from one of the new variants, increased infections coming out of Valentine's Day, or more testing resulting in more cases showing up.  Still too early for increased testing from people prepping for Spring Break.

Based on the rate at which daily cases have been decreasing since beginning of 2021, I estimate there will be 450k cases for the week in question. Even assuming that daily confirmed cases stays constant from this point forward, that would put us at around 580k cases/week.

Current linear trend puts daily cases well below 600k at a rough estimate but there has been some fluctuation so hedging slightly.
https://ourworldindata.org/coronavirus/country/united-states?country=~USA
I may be misunderstanding the question but  if the question the number of confirmed cases for one week in the US, then the most recent week had around 85K cases and the tend is going down.

Testing will come out low in the week 13 through 20 February 2021, largely due to adverse weather conditions across the U.S.
Once the situation will be cleared (probably exactly in the week 21 through 28 February 2021), there will be above-normal, maybe 20% higher than average for a week of testing capacity and activity (which could mean a 40% week-over-week increase). Even with constant or slightly dropping positivity rates, this will likely increase the absolute number of confirmed cases returned to at least 700,000, and in any case to more than what the current trend suggests.
Tricky date, tdon’t know if in time for uptick. 21/03 would make it easier.
Still heading south, and fast. But that drop should slow and we cannot be too certain too early as a result.

For the first time since November, the US has fell below 100,000 new coronavirus cases per day.  The current 7-day rolling total is 96.6K new cases per day.  This is trending in a good direction and amounts to 676,263 cases per week.  These rates would need to drop another 11% to be in the below 600,000 category.  While this is possible, we haven't seen those kind of rates since October.  But it does seem like rate across the Americas are dropping.

New cases have dropped dramatically since 1/22.  But they are still hovering about 100k a day and are steadily up from 89581 on 2/7 to 105353 on 2/11 (Superbowl effect?).  Looks like most people are thinking flat or down.  I am less optimistic.   The new strains will have a bigger effect than most people think. Everyone has gotten comfortable with the safety measures they have been taking. But those won't be nearly as effective for the new strains. In addition, it has been suggested that the new strains are more infectious because they deliver a higher viral load. This could cause symptoms to occur more quickly and are known to be more severe https://nymag.com/intelligencer/article/what-is-the-new-covid-19-strain-that-shut-down-england-u-k.html. So we might be a bit too comforted by the recent drop in cases. Couple that with the Superbowl and we might see another spike in the next month. Unfortunately, I think 750k is close to an expected value, so I am starting 50/50 on either side of this.
Still predicting just under 600,000, but very much only just.

Dialing it back a bit with recent uptick. OW Pandemic navigator currently has the centerpoint estimate of 83K for trailing 7 days of Feb 28, which would put the total at just under 600K: https://pandemicnavigator.oliverwyman.com/forecast?mode=country&region=United%20States&panel=baseline

the last data available from JHU git-hub : 729 530 weekly cases This confirms the trend I described of -170,000 cases per week
If -170,000/week the next week => 559,530 The crowd forecast now is more optimistic

The CDC projects that confirmed covid cases will be at approximately 668,000 for the week of the 21st, and other data seems to agree with this prediction. However, the recent superbowl as well as upcoming Valentine's Day could lead to a mild spike in covid cases, so I predict that the covid cases will likely be higher than the CDC's projection.

Assuming the current downward trend holds without hitting a bottom (admittedly very unlikely), the total confirmed cases is likely to be significantly below 600k. Confirmed cases today were 104K, down from 130.5K just 7 days prior on a relatively straight-forward downward trend. Assuming this holds, the week starting on the 21st is likely to see significantly less cases than 70k cases on that first day, and thus potentially less than 500k for that week.  Add to this the fact that the number of tests performed is also on a downward trend as of the 27th of Jan, and that the share of positive tests are similarly on a downward trend, I think a figure lower than 600k is quite likely.  Of course, vaccine rollout, introcution and spread of new variants, potential down-stream effects of superbowl gatherings etc. may all play a role.
Current positivity rate at 9.7% of those tested which is down from 11+% expect trend to continue downward. Also decrease in number of tests run, expect trend to continue to decrease
Case counts are falling rapidly. It’s somewhat of a battle between vaccine rollout and new variants, but at 77k new cases today I have to bet we will be lower in three weeks.

One particular model suggests that there will be around 900k cases, assuming extraneous factors remain steady -- which, under the light of the Biden administration and new restrictive policies, they may not. As a consequence of the yet-to-be-introduced policies, I'd argue that this model is incorrect and that it's more likely for there to be around 750k and below as time progresses and the vaccine is rapidly proliferated. https://pandemicnavigator.oliverwyman.com/forecast?mode=country&region=United%20States&panel=baseline https://ourworldindata.org/covid-vaccinations
Still decreasing rapidly. Anxious about the slow down as it will be very hard to predict the magnitude of that.

Cases have trended down in the U.S. by 34% over the next few weeks which has led some to predict fewer that 600,000, However, I worry that Super Bowl parties combined with the new variants that have presented themselves will cause another rise in this week, probably getting closer to 800,000 cases (the amount that were seen over this past week, except trending upwards instead of down).
14 day trend is down 36 per cent so this is likely to continue through February before rising again in late March/April

Uptick from Superbowl gatherings, opening of restaurants and schools in major metro areas like NYC is expected but will vaccination rate curb any potential increase in numbers? There is a definite downward trend nationwide but by how much can it be sustained as things further open

The rapid drop in cases continues, however I had made an error in my maths which has lowered my confidence. The result is going to come in very tight about the 600,000 mark. Still think under, but there is too long to go and too much noise in a non-ideal system to be too confident.

Optimistic case: We seem to be at around 842,000 cases for the week as of February 6 with cases dropping 10 to 25% w-o-w in many states.[1]  As others have noted, vaccinations, masks, and social distancing are working under new national leadership. Pessimistic case: A Morning Consult Poll finds that 27% of adults are likely to attend or host a Super Bowl party with friends or relatives outside their house.[2] With approximately 228 million adults, that means 61 million adults will be shouting, cheering, as well as drinking and eating chicken wings, both of which require removing a mask. The CDC has collected forecasts ranging from 440,000 to 1.1 million weekly infections for the week ending February 27 from its partners in forecasting.[3]  When I looked at the underlying data and discussion, however, the CDC noted that the vast majority of forecaster partners use a static model, assuming everything will stay the same with respect to interventions, including social distancing.  Therefore the average value 770,000 weekly cases does not account for what is transpiring right now on Super Bowl Sunday. In my estimation, then, the most likely scenario is flat-lining the current rate for another three weeks or a much gentler decline than we would have had under all the very favorable conditions in the last several weeks.  So I put the balance of probability at 750,000 to 1,050,000.   [1] https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/weekly-covid-cases?tab=chart&stackMode=absolute&time=2020-03-16..latest&region=World
[2] https://www.verizon.com/about/sites/default/files/2021-02/Deck%20-%20Verizon_Super%20Bowl%20LV%20Plans_public.pdf
[3] https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/cases-updates/forecasts-cases.html
Current weekly pattern is dropping rapidly.
Adjusting downward. I was basing my projections on OW model but I don’t think they are accurately capture ring the double whammy of the vaccine and holiday surge fading.

According to Worldometers, the 7-day moving average of daily cases decreased from 197,895 on 20 Jan to 129,912 on 4 Feb.  This was a reduction rate of 4,858 cases per day.  assuming a linear decrease, on 21 Feb the 7-day moving average of new cases would be 52,184.  assuming a constant rate of decrease until 21 Feb, but then zero decrease the entire week, there would be 365,288 new cases the week beginning 28 Feb.  It will not be the case that the number of cases decrease linearly, then remain constant that entire week, but that quick math allows for the gradually decreasing curve that appears is repeating in the coming weeks.
Trend seems to be on the lower end at the moment

NPR has 136k cases per day, which is just under 1m/week with rates dropping off by 30k cases per day over each of the past few weeks which is a drop of 210k per week. 2 weeks like this get down to about 600k, which feels a bit steep. CDC projecting down to about 800k over next few weeks. So feel like quick drop off, but not so far as 600k.

A smooth curve would say about 580,000. Is the Superbowl enough to notch in a 3.5% increase over expected in # of cases? Likely. A 30% increase to hit 750k? People gathering for the Superbowl probably aren't different enough from people who would gather anyways. More importantly, a set of superspreading events like Superbowl parties would take weeks for the exponential growth to occur that makes them super, so pretty unlikely imo.

Forecast 500K-700K
Expecting the decline to continue but flatten slightly over next two weeks as effects of mask-wearing and vaccine balance against lessening risk-avoidance by some.

Oliverwyman pandemic navigator estimates 125K cases Feb 14, 117K Feb 21. Assuming cases fall at that rate, gets you to 109K rolling 7 day average Feb 28, which comes out to 763K cases.  Assuming a rough standard deviation of 140K (20k per day), but am applying a little bit of an overlay to cap the upside of the projection given the impact of the vaccine coming online. Given the current run rate is about 950K per week average, I give extreemely low change to surprising to the upside of that. https://pandemicnavigator.oliverwyman.com/forecast?mode=country&region=United%20States&panel=baseline

the last data available from JHU git-hub: 01/27-01/21=25546693-24606222=940,471 The number of cases has been declining in recent weeks and is expected to continue to decline as a result of continued policy measures and the effect of vaccines offsetting the effect of new variants.
Between 01/25 and 02/01, -170,000 new case (source: https://ourworldindata.org/coronavirus-data-explorer?zoomToSelection=true&time=2020-11-06..latest&country=~USA&region=World&casesMetric=true&interval=weekly&perCapita=true&smoothing=0&pickerMetric=total_cases&pickerSort=desc)
And ourwolrdindata says 1,130,000 case during 01/27-01/21 If -170,000/week=>430,471
But this scenario is too optimistic: the crowd forecast is today only 18% for fewer than 600,000

This seems like a question of whether Superbowl Sunday becomes SuperSpreader Sunday, with any infectious spread leading to hospitalization 14-21 days later... 
Infections may be balanced by vaccination campaigns, but only slightly in this short-term period. I am less optimistic than the crowd in a dramatic drop in cases that week. The last week below 1M cases was 2 Nov 2020.

The Spanish Flu had three peaks in cases and the United States is coming off of its second wave.  Will a third wave occur before the end of February?  From past pandemics, it appears there are several weeks, at least, in between each wave, so one can assume that the rates will continue to decrease or level off at some point in the next three weeks. The cases in the US appear to be decreasing in the recent weeks.  This graph does not function in a linear fashion, but to make the math easy the projected numbers assume that the cases decrease at a standard 15% rate, which is the average of percentage decreases for the past three weeks. Feb 1-7 - 911.5K cases
Feb 8-14 - 774.7K cases
Feb 15-21 - 658.5K cases
Feb 22-28 - 559.7K cases However, the cases count hasn't been below 600K per week since the end of October, so attaining this level would be quite surprising.  With exponential functions, they come down quickly and level off in a relatively smooth manner.  After the last wave, the case count decreased by a smaller and smaller percentage each week.   Feb 1-7 - 15% decrease - 911.5K cases
Feb 8-14 - 10% decrease - 820.4K cases
Feb 15-21 - 5% decrease - 779.3K cases
Feb 22-28 - 3% decrease - 756K cases - this is the number that the forecast was based on.

Current rate of decline seems to be about a quarter million cases a week, at 1 million cases a week right now based on Our World in Data. If that continued over the next 3 weeks we'd be at 250,000 cases a week. But that's an extreme optimistic view in my opinion, and while I'm generally optimistic on vaccines and cases declining from here, I think the decline is probably more likely to slow. It's also possible it plateau's, or even ticks back up a bit by then. I'm putting the high end at about where we are, and the low end at 250k a week, centered on in between that. Note to self to verify data I'm using matches the data to be used for the question. Weekly cases: https://ourworldindata.org/coronavirus-data-explorer?zoomToSelection=true&time=2020-03-01..latest&country=~USA&region=World&casesMetric=true&interval=weekly&perCapita=true&smoothing=0&pickerMetric=total_cases&pickerSort=desc
Think cases more encouraging for US than deaths, little correlation in mortality rates. Cases should average circa 100k and vaccination programme only going to push it down.
